translated: Sutra of the Dharma Mirror
Translated by An Xuan, Cavalry General of Arsakes in the Later Han Dynasty

Thus have I heard: Once, the Blessed One was dwelling in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park in the city of Shravasti, together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhikshus and 500 bodhisattvas, including Maitreya, Manjushri, Ajita, and Puxian, the foremost of the bodhisattvas.
At that time, the Blessed One was surrounded by several hundred people, to whom he was expounding the sutras.

At that time, in the city of Shravasti there was a householder named Sudatta, who left the city of Shravasti with a group of 500 people and went to the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park, where he approached the Blessed One. Upon arrival, he bowed his head at the Blessed One's feet and then sat down to one side.

There were also the householder Aiyue, Naixue, Shanshou, Dawei, Jiagudu, Longwei, and Disi. This entire group of five hundred people went together to where the Buddha was. Upon arrival, they bowed their heads at the feet of the Honored One and sat in front of the Honored One.
All those householders had given rise to the aspiration for the great path, and they had together created roots of virtue, having determined the unsurpassed true path, except for Jiagudu.

Then, the very householder, seeing the assembly of householders gathered and seated, rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, bowed with his head at the feet, knelt for a long time, put his palms together, and said:
I wish to ask about something. Will the Honored One have the leisure to explain what I ask?
The Honored One replied to the very householder, saying:ğŸ”½Very good, very good!

The Tathagata always has leisure to expound what you ask, householder. You may ask, as you wish, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, and I will expound for you what you ask, satisfying your intention.
Sujata asked the Buddha, saying:
Now, Blessed One!

If clansmen and women give rise to the intention to seek the unsurpassed true path, delight in the great path, practice the great path, wish to attain the great path, wish to descend the great path, wish to know the great path, vow to deliver all beings, comfort beings, and protect beings, their vow is:ğŸ”½'Those who are not yet liberated, I shall liberate them;
those who are not yet released, I shall release them;
those who are not yet at peace, I shall comfort and reassure them;
those who have not yet attained nirvana, I shall lead them to nirvana.'

In order to accept the heavy responsibility of all sentient beings and to save and protect them, they vow to make such a vast and great vow, knowing that the various evils of birth and death are many, yet their minds are not discouraged, and they do not turn back in their minds even for countless eons of birth and death.
This, O Benefactor!
There are bodhisattvas who leave home to pursue the Way, and there are those who remain as laypeople.
Excellent, O Benefactor!

You have compassion for sentient beings and have extended this great Way to flourish the Three Jewels, and also to cause all the scriptures to remain for a long time. The TathÄgata should explain the Dharma of virtue for the bodhisattvas who remain as laypeople.
What is it, O Benefactor!
For the bodhisattvas who remain as laypeople and follow the TathÄgata's teachings, without violating or damaging their original vows, namely the unsurpassed true Way;
Also, in the present life there is practice without offense, and in the next life one goes to the superior path;
Also, those who are required are the multitude of benefactors!

For those who leave the home-life to pursue the Way, they abandon hatred and love, shave their beards and hair, put on Dharma robes, and at home with faith, leave the home-life to pursue the Way, showing their teachings, Dharma methods, proper methods, and virtuous methods.
Those who are required are the multitude of benefactors!
For those who leave the home-life to pursue the Way and those who remain at home, how should they cultivate it?
Then the multitude of benefactors praised the householder:
Excellent, excellent, householder!
Now you have come to know to ask the TathÄgata about the practice of the householder and renunciant bodhisattvas.
Therefore, householder!
Listen to what I say, strive, be diligent, and contemplate it well, for the bodhisattva who remains at home to pursue the Way cultivates the practice of virtuous goodness.
The great householder accepted the teaching and listened.
The multitude of benefactors said:
In this way, householder!
For bodhisattvas living at home who are practicing the Way, they should take refuge in the Buddha, take refuge in the Dharma, and take refuge in the Saá¹ƒgha.
With the merit of taking refuge, they transform it into the unsurpassed true Way.
Householder!
What does it mean to take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha?

I shall attain the thirty-two marks of a great man with which to adorn my Buddha body, and also with those roots of virtue attain the thirty-two marks of a great man. With those roots of virtue, I shall diligently practice and progress.
For bodhisattvas living at home who take refuge in the Buddha, it is like this.
What does it mean to take refuge in the Dharma?

It means to respect the Dharma, seek the Dharma, desire the Dharma, delight in the joy of the Dharma, to uphold the Dharma, rely on the Dharma, protect the Dharma, be careful with the Dharma, abide in accordance with the Dharma, follow the Dharma methods, uphold the Dharma canon, cultivate the power of the Dharma, seek the wealth of the Dharma, cultivate the stillness of the Dharma, and perform Dharma activities. I too shall distribute this Dharma throughout the heavens and the world.
This is how a bodhisattva living at home takes refuge in the Dharma.
What does it mean to take refuge in the Saá¹…gha?

If a bodhisattva living at home sees a stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, arhat, or one who has attained the path of a disciple, he should respect them, serve them and make offerings to them, honor them as teachers, and treat them with propriety.
If by serving those who uphold the true Dharma and true methods, one can attain this aspiration, then I too shall attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
By lecturing and teaching the sÅ«tras, accomplishing the virtue of disciples, and being respected by them, isn't it also admirable?
Householders who are bodhisattvas take refuge in the Saá¹…gha in this way.
Moreover, householder,
bodhisattvas take refuge in the Buddha by cultivating four dharmas.
What are the four?
First, never abandoning the aspiration for enlightenment; second, never violating the precepts; third, never cutting off great compassion; fourth, never following other paths.
These are the four dharmas.
Householders who are bodhisattvas take refuge in the Buddha in this way.
Moreover, householder, they take refuge in the Dharma by cultivating four dharmas.
What are the four?
First, those who speak about the Dharma should be served and followed;
second, the Dharma that is heard should be revered;
third, the Dharma that is heard should be contemplated from beginning to end;
Fourth, as one hears the Dharma, one should explain it to others according to one's ability.
These are the four dharmas.
Householders who are bodhisattvas take refuge in the Dharma in this way.
Moreover, householder,
cultivating four dharmas is taking refuge in the Saá¹…gha.
What are the four?
First, one should give rise to the mind of a disciple, and be joyful towards all the wise;
second, one should accumulate things, and transform them with the accumulation of the Dharma;
third, one should rely on the Saá¹…gha that has reliance and certainty, and not rely on the Saá¹…gha of disciples;
fourth, one should seek the virtues of disciples, but not measure them with those virtues.
These are the four dharmas.
Householders who are bodhisattvas take refuge in the Saá¹…gha in this way.
Moreover, householder,
when practicing the path at home, seeing the TathÄgata is practicing mindfulness of the Buddha, which is taking refuge in the Buddha;
Having heard the Dharma, one should contemplate the Dharma, this is taking refuge in the Dharma;
If one has already seen the noble assembly of the TathÄgata and still contemplates the meaning of the Way, this is taking refuge in the assembly.
Moreover, householder!
Practicing the path at home, giving with the aspiration to encounter the Buddha is taking refuge in the Buddha;
If one gives in order to uphold the true Dharma, this is taking refuge in the Dharma;
If one gives in order to attain the unsurpassed true Way, this is taking refuge in the Sangha.
Moreover, householder, those who practice the path at home!
If one cultivates the conduct of a virtuous man and does not engage in the conduct of an ordinary person, that is the conduct of a virtuous man.
Seeking wealth through the Dharma and not through non-Dharma, through righteousness and not through unrighteousness, is also called right livelihood.
Not harassing others, but leading them through the Dharma.
Having much wealth, practicing the thought of impermanence, receiving one's treasures, thus always flourishing.

Giving offerings to parents, friends, ministers, siblings, and relatives, it is out of respect for them. To servants, guests, and attendants, one looks after them with impartiality, and also teaches and transforms them.
This is the special Dharma, and it is also to accept heavy responsibilities. This is called the heavy responsibility of sentient beings.
Vigorously practicing without slacking off, not accepting heavy responsibilities, and not accepting them, this is called the disciples' affairs of each Buddha's wisdom.
Accomplishing sentient beings without weariness, not longing for the happiness of the body, but bringing about the happiness of sentient beings.
Gain, loss, slander, praise, flattery, criticism, suffering, and joy do not cause one to waver, transcending worldly dharmas. Being wealthy and having possessions does not bring joy;
Moreover, in the three paths, there is no gain, no praise, no fame, and no reward.
What is done is thoroughly contemplated, and accepting the correct brings joy. Seeing and knowing the essential meaning of deviant acceptance, one has the correct practice.
The two aspects of praise and blame are used to eliminate attachment and attain one's vows. One worries about the affairs of others and does not neglect one's own affairs.
When one has shown kindness to others, one never expects repayment. One performs various acts of kindness and knows gratitude and reciprocation, and creates acts of kindness and virtue.

To the poor, one gives wealth; to those in fear, one provides peace and comfort; to those in sorrow, one alleviates their worries; to the weak, one patiently endures them; to the powerful, one diminishes their arrogance and abandons their exceptional arrogance and excessive pride.
One respectfully venerates the elders and serves those of great learning, and is able to ask the wise and know the straight.
One's appearance is straightforward and not hypocritical to the multitude, and one has skillful means. Can one seek virtue and goodness?
One is not content with much learning and is insatiable. One correctly cultivates diligent effort and firmly encounters the sages.
One follows the sages and venerates them. One serves those of great learning and asks the wise, and thus manifests straightforwardness.
Not keeping secret the various sÅ«tras, as heard, manifesting them, and understanding their meaning upon hearing them.

All desires and pleasures are considered impermanent, not longing for or cherishing the body, contemplating one's lifespan as like a dewdrop in the morning, and considering all possessions as like illusory clouds.

Family members and guests are considered enemies, wives, children, and relatives are considered the realm of indiscriminate hell, considering all one has as suffering, and fields, houses, and all possessions are always considered faults.
The virtue one seeks to attain is considered indestructible;
living at home is considered dangerous;
friends, ministers, siblings, and relatives are considered the lords of hell;
day and night are considered the same.ğŸ”½With an unreal body, one receives the thought of reality;ğŸ”½with an unreal lifespan, one receives the thought of reality;
with unreal wealth, one receives the thought of real wealth.
If they respect and serve people with propriety and courtesy, then they use their unreal body to receive reality.
If they do not destroy the roots of goodness from the past, and moreover increase them, then they use their unreal life to receive reality.
If they overcome stinginess and practice generosity, then they use their unreal wealth to receive reality.
This is the practice of a virtuous man for a bodhisattva living at home to cultivate the path, to act in this way without fault;
it is the teaching of the TathÄgata, the teaching of the Dharma;
it does not destroy or harm their original vow, this is called the unsurpassed, true path.
Then in the present life there is practice without fault, and in the next life one also falls into the path of excellence.
Moreover, householder!
For a bodhisattva living at home to cultivate the path, they should uphold the precepts for themselves, referring to upholding the five precepts.
Therefore, they do not enjoy killing, do not harm any living creature, and do not harass others;
Therefore, they do not enjoy stealing others' things, are content with their own wealth, do not think of others' wealth, and even with regard to tiny grass and straw, do not take what is not given;
Therefore, they do not enjoy engaging in sexual misconduct, are content with their own wives, and do not delight in looking at other women.
Their minds are always afflicted, thinking that desire is all suffering.

If they give rise to thoughts of desire, even towards their own wife, they contemplate impurity, fearfully thinking that the affairs of desire are troublesome, without fear or suffering, and that attachment is impermanent. With the thought of pure joy, they aspire to attain the mind, and then think, In this way, I should cultivate myself.
If I have thoughts of desire, I will not act on them, let alone do so frequently?
Therefore, they do not enjoy speaking falsely, but speak truthfully and sincerely;
It is because of the nature of not being deceitful;
It is because of the mind of not being defeated, being sincere, and speaking as one sees and hears;
Carefully guarding the Dharma of the sÅ«tras, not using one's body or life, thus not speaking falsely.
Therefore, one should not delight in drinking alcohol, not being intoxicated, not confused, not agitated, not punished, but following the transformation, with a strong will and right knowledge.

If one can revive the intention of giving, then all that I have I will give to others. Seeking food I will give food, seeking drink I will give drink, seeking vehicles I will give vehicles, seeking clothing I will give clothing. Thus I give alcohol to others in order to establish their will, such is the perfection of giving.
For this reason, if someone asks for something, then I will give it to them.
At that time I can give alcohol, causing them to follow the transformation of the will, just as I know myself to be practicing without confusion.
Why is this so?
Now, a bodhisattva fulfills the wishes of sentient beings through giving, and the perfection of giving is like this.
A bodhisattva living at home may give alcohol to others without incurring fault.
Therefore, householder!
A bodhisattva, with the roots of virtue cultivated, transforms them into unsurpassed true enlightenment. If cultivated well, one should carefully guard these five precepts.

Moreover, one should be different. One should not slander others, but reconcile those who are in dispute. One should not speak harshly, but with gentle words. One should always speak to others first, and not with frivolous speech. One should speak meaningfully, speak in accordance with the Dharma, speak in a timely manner, and speak in accordance with the situation.
One should not have a web of delusion, but bestow peace and security upon sentient beings.
One's mind should not be in disarray, but always adorn oneself with the power of patience.
Using right view, they abandon wrong views, and pay homage to the Buddhas, not to other gods.
Moreover, householder,
those who practice the path at home, whether in villages, towns, counties, or countries, should protect the sutras and Dharma there. How should one protect the sutras?
Those who lack faith should be taught with faith;
those who are stingy should be taught with generosity;
those with evil precepts should be taught with precepts;ğŸ”½those with confused minds should be taught with patience;ğŸ”½the lazy should be taught with diligence;
those with lost intentions should be taught with meditation;
those with wrong knowledge should be taught with wisdom;
those who lack wealth should be made wealthy;
the sick should be given medicine;ğŸ”½the orphaned should be given family;
the homeless should be given a home;
For those without support, he becomes their support. For all those in the villages and towns, he protects the Dharma in this way.
Householder!
If a bodhisattva teaches one, two, three, up to a hundred people, causing them all to cultivate the Dharma of various merits,
that bodhisattva then increases his compassion for sentient beings and strengthens his vast vows.
He makes the following vow:
'As for those difficult to transform people who have not yet attained accomplishment, I will not attain supreme true enlightenment.
Why is this?
It is because I now make this vow for their sake.
I do not do it for the sake of the honest, the unflattering, the unpretentious, the guarded, or the admonishing virtuous ones.
It is precisely for the sake of these people that I make this vow, but only in order to cause these people who hear the Dharma to transform me through the Dharma.
Using this, one makes a vow to oneself.
I will always use this to strengthen my practice, and my efforts will not be in vain.
If people see me, they will all have good faith.
If a householder arrives at a place where a bodhisattva resides, if he does not praise it, and all the people fall into the evil destinies, that is the fault of the bodhisattva.
Householder!
It is like a village, town, county, district, or country where there is a good doctor. If there is anyone who does not end their life, all the people will blame that doctor.
In the same way, householder!
If a bodhisattva arrives at a place and does not praise it, and all the people fall into the evil destinies, the TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One will blame that bodhisattva.
Householder!
Therefore, a householder bodhisattva makes this vow for himself:
Even if I go to a country or town where the foolish gather, I will not allow even one person to fall into a bad rebirth.
Moreover, householder!
Those who cultivate the path at home should understand the evils of the household.
Being in the household harms the foundation of all good, because the household is without liberation, and it harms the pure Dharma. Therefore, it is called the household.

Being in the household means dwelling in all kinds of toil, dwelling in evil thoughts, dwelling in evil actions, not transforming oneself or guarding oneself, dwelling with foolish ordinary people, gathering with those who are not truthful. Therefore, it is called the household.
The household is a name, and those who are in it do not do what is not in accord with the Way.
Because of being in it, one is not respectful, to one's own parents, to those who have passed away, to the elders and sages. Therefore, it is called the household.
County officials, prison cells, beatings, scolding, and even death all come from that, and therefore it is called a home.
Being in that is called entering the evil paths, falling into desires, falling into anger, being in all fears, and being in ignorance - this is called a home.

Not being careful to protect the precepts, being far from the matter of concentration, not cultivating the matter of wisdom, not attaining liberation, and not giving rise to the knowledge and vision of liberation - therefore it is called a home.

Being in that, there is love for parents, love for brothers and sisters, love for wives and children, love for houses and property, love for servants and possessions, love for seeking wealth without being content - therefore it is called a home.
This home life is difficult to satisfy!
It is like the great ocean to which all rivers flow.
This home life is insatiable!
It is like fire obtaining fuel.
For those living in households, there are many thoughts of non-abiding and cessation.
It is like wind, which is considered to be without abiding and is still sinking.
It is like delicious food mixed with poison, which brings all kinds of suffering.
It is like an enemy appearing as a friend, which is a mistake in one's conduct.
It is not the practice of the scriptures, which leads to disputes.
They constantly disagree with each other.
It is full of faults.
Because of the causes and conditions of practicing good and evil, one is always suspected by others.
It is not human.
Because of the existence of inversion.
It is not good.
Although there is skillful deception in goodness, one can still see its nature and conduct.
It is like the body of an actor.
Because of rapid transformation.
It is like a magician.
When people first gather, their conduct is not sincere.
It is like a dream.
Because all success and failure have a beginning and an end.
It is like morning dew,
Because it quickly disappears.
It is like a drop of honey,
Because it has little flavor.
It is like a net of thorns,
Because form, sound, smell, taste, and touch are harmful.
It is like a worm in a needle hole,
Because unwholesome thoughts are its food.
It is like a disobedient person,
Because it deceives each other.
It is always fearful,
Because the mind is disturbed.
It is very crowded,
Because it is harmed by officials, thieves, enemies, and evil kings.
The pleasures of the home life have little flavor,
Because there are many faults and losses.
Householder,
The bodhisattva who lives at home understands the faults of the home life in this way.
Moreover, householder,
For those who practice the path while living at home, giving is a treasure. If what has been given belongs to me, then what is in the home does not belong to me;
If one has already given, it is a treasure; if one stays at home, it is not a treasure.
If one has already given, it is wealth; if one stays at home, it is no wealth.
If one has already given, it is the end of toil; if one stays at home, toil increases.ğŸ”½If one has already given, it is not one's own; if one stays at home, it is already one's own.
If one has already given, it is not existence; if one stays at home, it is taken to be existence.
If one has already given, it is inexhaustible; if one stays at home, it is not permanent.
If one has already given, one does not guard it again; if one stays at home, it is guarded.
If one has already given, it is the practice of the wise; if one stays at home, it is the intention of the ordinary person.
If one has already given, it is based on the path of liberation; if one stays at home, it is based on the heterodox part.
If one has already given, it is praised by the Buddha; if one stays at home, it is praised by the foolish.
Householder!
For the bodhisattva who cultivates the path at home, giving is a treasure like this.
Therefore, when one sees a person come to seek something, one gives rise to three thoughts.
What are the three?
The thought of good friends, the thought of relying on the path of transcendence, and the thought of striving to be born with wealth. These three thoughts are born.
Again, three thoughts are created.
What are the three?
The thought of respecting the teachings of the TathÄgata, the thought of subduing evil, and the thought of not expecting merit in return.
Why is this?
If this bodhisattva, when someone comes to request something, considers greed, anger, and delusion to be thin, what can be done about those who are thin?
If one does not begrudge any possessions and gives them away, this is thin greed;
If one extends kindness to those who come to request things, this is thin anger;
If one gives and transforms this into all agility, this is thin delusion.
Moreover, householder!
Having seen someone come to request things, one will soon accomplish the practice of the six pÄramitÄs.
How does one accomplish that?
If one is able to give without being stingy when someone comes and asks for something, this is the perfection of giving.
If one gives with the intention of attaining the Way, this is the perfection of precepts.
If one does not become angry, this is the perfection of patience.
Even if one still thinks, What is the use of food?
One should strengthen one's resolve and not give up one's practice, this is the perfection of vigor.
Whether one wishes to give or has already given, if one is not agitated and has no regrets, this is the perfection of meditation.
If one has already given and does not expect any blessings in return, this is the perfection of wisdom.
Householder!
The bodhisattva uses giving to accomplish the practice of the six perfections in this way.
Moreover, householder!
This is considered by the laypeople to be the separation from and abandonment of anger and confusion, the method of parting from loved ones.
If one obtains a child, wealth, rice, or grain, one should not be overjoyed;
If everything is lost, one should not be disheartened.
Having observed that all things are like illusions, one should not dwell on thoughts of permanence.

This illusory practice leads to this. Therefore, parents, wife, children, slaves, servants, and guests are not mine, and I am also not theirs. I am also not existent, and I should not be existent. Because I am not existent, I exist.
Now, for their sake, I commit evil deeds, but only in this present life, not for future lives.
This past existence is not something I should protect.
Moreover, what I have, I should protect.
What is meant by what I have?
It refers to the roots of the path of giving, transforming, tranquility, and self-guarding, and also the virtuous basis of concealment. This is what I have.
If they come to where I reside, it is then following me. They also do not use their bodies and lives, or for the sake of sons, daughters, wives, and children, to create evil deeds.
Therefore, for those who live at home and have their own wives, they should create three thoughts.
What are the three?
The thought of impermanence, the thought of not being long, and the thought of separation. These three thoughts should be created.
One should create three thoughts again.
What are the three?

If one is in joy and pleasure, one should seek it in suffering in the next life. If one is in food and drink, one should seek it in misfortune and crime. If one is in happiness, one should seek it in suffering. One should create these three thoughts.
One should create three thoughts again.
What are the three?
The thought of accumulation, the thought of dissipation, and the thought of what belongs to the secular world. One should create these three thoughts.
One should create three thoughts again.
What are the three?
The thought of entering hell, the thought of entering the realm of animals, and the thought of entering the realm of spirits and ghosts. One should create these three thoughts.
One should further create three thoughts.
What are the three?
The thought of goblins, the thought of a pestle and mortar, and the thought of physical appearance - one should create these three thoughts.
One should further create three thoughts.
What are the three?
The thought of non-self, the thought of no owner, and the thought of borrowed metaphors - one should create these three thoughts.
Householder!
If one contemplates these various thoughts, a bodhisattva living at home should contemplate his own body and his wife in this way.
Therefore, one should not love one's son. If one has no love for one's unborn son, one will not extend it to all people under Heaven.
Therefore, one should admonish oneself with three things and admonish one's own mind.
What are the three?
The mind of equality is the Way, not the deviant mind;
Right practice is the Way, not deviant practice;
Not much practice is the Way, much practice is not.
Therefore, admonish yourself three times, admonish your own mind, and create the thought of an enemy towards your child, thinking, This is my enemy, not my friend.
Why is it so?
It is because of them that I violate the compassionate Buddha's teachings and admonitions, causing me to greatly increase my love for them.
People should cut their own minds like loving their children, and extend love to sentient beings;
If they love their own bodies, they should extend compassion to sentient beings.
Therefore, one should contemplate the origin and source of this, which is different from where I come from.
Sentient beings were also my children in past lives, and I was also a sentient being's child. This is the fault of birth and death, for which there is no suitable escape.
Why is it so?
The path of coming and going always involves separation and action, turning back to become enemies.
I should now cultivate myself, causing me to have no friends, and also me to have no enemies.
Why is it so?
Because of desire, one creates knowledge, and in order to create more, one creates enemies. All evil is due to desire.
All sentient beings are not me, but you cannot use the idea of right and wrong to judge. By thoroughly understanding all sutras,
why is it so?
Those who practice correctly attain the correct path, while those who practice wrongly attain the wrong path.
Now I do not have wrong practices, but have a correct attitude and practices towards sentient beings, and can thus attain all abilities.
Householder!
For bodhisattvas living at home, all things are not to be longed for, not to be admired, not to be indulged in, not to be loved, and not to be attached to, and should be like this.
Moreover, householder!
If a householder, when someone comes to ask for something, if he does not wish to give them that thing, he should still admonish his own mind;
If I do not give this thing as a gift, then I will surely be separated from this thing.
Whether one desires or does not desire, when death arrives, these things will also be abandoned by me, and I will also abandon them.
If one gives away treasures and ends [life], I give away these things, and at the time of death, the mind is at ease.
If one contemplates in this way, but is unable to give away those things, then one uses the four phrases to decline when others come to request things.
What are the four?
I am powerless, and the many virtues are not yet accomplished;
I am at the beginning of the great path, and the intention to give is not free;
I have the view of receiving, and am in my own practice, please wait for me, wise one, do not press me;
What I practice, I am able to carry out, as I have received it, then I am able to fulfill your wishes and those of the people of the world.
This is how one declines when others come to request things.
Moreover, householder!

As for those who cultivate the Way at home, if they are separated from the teachings of their teachers, when there is no Buddha in the world, no one to show them the scriptures, and they do not encounter the sages, they should bow to the Buddhas of the ten directions, and also to those who sought the Way in the past, with vast aspirations, wishing that all will accomplish the virtues of the Buddha's Dharma, and think of them with joy on their behalf.
Then, three times during the day and three times at night, discuss the three types of sutra matters.
All the evil deeds done in the past, confess and repent, change the past and cultivate the future, seek compassion from all Buddhas, and because of the Dharma, have pity on them;
Also have pity on them with immeasurable and boundless Dharma.
Moreover, householder!

As for those who cultivate the Way at home, they should understand the rules and methods of calming the mind. Therefore, if they see the rules and methods of calming the mind of the renunciant, they should respect his Dharma robes, for they are the robes of the precepts, concentration, and wisdom practiced by the Blessed One, the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Being without evil is to be free from all evil, and that is the symbol of the sages and immortals.
Therefore, one should also respect them, and have compassion for those renunciants, for this is not the conduct of the virtuous.
As for the robes, they are called:
The robes of the tranquil one, the disciplined one, the one with spiritual powers, and the TathÄgata, are the symbols of the practice of taming and purifying the undisciplined.
Moreover, the TathÄgata said:

This is to give rise to the intention to leave the household life. There has never been a bodhisattva who attained the Way while living in a household. Householder!

The practice of the renunciant bodhisattva, may you also manifest a few subtle wholesome [actions].
The essential, O Benefactor!

Moreover, for the bodhisattva who has left the household life to cultivate the Way, there are ten virtues of contentment, and the body wears the Dharma robes.

It is because of shame that the body wears the Dharma robes;ğŸ”½it is in order to avoid wind and heat that the body wears the Dharma robes;

He suffers from the affliction of leaving the pleasures of desire, therefore he does not enjoy the pleasures of desire;
He enjoys the attainment of purity, therefore he eliminates the pleasures of various afflictions;
He does not use corpulence as the practice of the Way;
He practices in the heavy responsibility of the Way of the sages, and he also cultivates himself;
As if there were a Dharma robe at one time, because he wears the Dharma robes.
With these ten virtues, he observes himself until the end of his life, living in a quiet place, and does not go begging.

He uses his own karma for his livelihood, not other non-karma;

If he wants to beg for alms from others, but if others do not want to give, he does not add to their suffering;

I will myself eat the food of practice, in order not to go against the teachings of the TathÄgata, in order to accomplish the basis of contentment and heavy responsibility, in order to subdue arrogance, and in order to accomplish the basis of the virtue of the invisible crown;
I also see giving, as if teaching myself;

If I go to beg, I will not be able to have any preference for men or women, because our intention is for all people in the world, in order to accomplish the heavy responsibility of all skillful wisdom.
This, householder!
The ten virtues, for a renunciant bodhisattva, are to contemplate oneself until the end of life, to dwell in a secluded place, and not to go begging.
If someone comes to invite one to their dwelling place, if that person's mind believes and delights in the Way, I should not go there;
If one goes to eat, if one is able to benefit oneself and also able to benefit others, one may go to receive offerings.
My teaching for bodhisattvas is to seek from them.
These are the ten virtues by which one can observe oneself and dwell under a tree.

To go wherever one pleases;

To be insatiable in hearing;

To not depart from being focused on the five supernormal knowledges, to flourish the six perfections, to turn away from all sharp intentions, to not choose to abandon, and to practice the wisdom of skillful means;

Praised by the buddhas, extolled by the sages, what those who wish to cross the world rely on.

Postscript to the Sutra of the Dharma Mirror Postscript to the Sutra of the Dharma Mirror:
Without illuminating the mirror, one does not see one's own form; without praising the holy sutra, one does not see one's own feelings.

Feelings have truth and falsehood, nature has flexibility and firmness, will has purity and fierceness, intention has obscurity and clarity, cognition has shallowness and depth, and cannot be the same.
Without seeing the holy scriptures, there is no way to illuminate oneself. The Buddha therefore composed the sutra called the Sutra of the Dharma Mirror and bestowed it upon certain people.

Moreover, many of the original characters and phrases have gradually been erased, changed, and rearranged, causing the sentences to be mismatched, the sounds to be inconsistent, the meanings to be contradictory, and the continuity to be disrupted, greatly losing their appropriateness.
The scriptures established by the Sage have concise words and correct meanings, considered to be complete, without any flaws, and cannot be further added or subtracted.
It is like the four limbs received from one's parents, with their length, shortness, beauty, and ugliness each having their original basis!
How can they be changed again?
What is called adding to them makes them look like calves, subtracting from them makes them look like sores.

Moreover, the ancient characters of secular poetry, books, rituals, and music, even though they are not the correct forms, the later generations of students dare not change them, all respecting the ancient classics and passing them on to each other. How much more so for this scripture, which is bright and established by the Sage!

The myriad sages and immortals in the heavens above and below all bow their heads and accept it as a clear model. Those who study increase their wisdom, and those who practice attain liberation, their number being countless.

Yet in this latter-day world, late learners, whose knowledge is not yet extensive, use their private opinions to denigrate the correct words, and go against the scriptures. How could this not be delightful!
Calling themselves Buddhist learners, yet going against the Buddha's teachings, what else do they seek?
